Following Sri's snippet test, cutting and pasting to change the order of
composites in a shell with row layout produces the following stack trace:

java.lang.RuntimeException: IWAV0185E should not be here
	at
org.eclipse.ve.internal.java.codegen.core.JavaSourceTranslator$SharedToLocalUpdater.Reload(JavaSourceTranslator.java:112)
	at
org.eclipse.ve.internal.java.codegen.core.JavaSourceTranslator$SharedToLocalUpdater.run(JavaSourceTranslator.java:516)
	at
org.eclipse.ve.internal.java.codegen.java.SnippetParseJob.doRun(SnippetParseJob.java:72)
	at
org.eclipse.ve.internal.java.codegen.util.ReverseParserJob.run(ReverseParserJob.java:57)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:67)

A couple problems were detected. 
(1) NPEs were happening depending on whether the Shell's expressions were
getting processed first, or the removed composite's. This was because if shell's
were processed first, seeing the removal of 'createComposite()' he would dipose
the upcoming composite, but the snippet update obliviously went ahead with
merging the disposed bean and NPEd. Released BDMMerger for this.
(2) There was a classcast exception arising when one drops a composite from the
UI and removes it from source without saving it. Turned out that the
'createComposite()' expression had its argument set to an EObject when dropped,
but while decoding he expected a BeanPart - hence causing exceptions. If one
saved and opened the file, the argument would have been a BeanPart and life was
good. This problem happens only when one it is dropped from UI and then
re-decoded due to offset changes. Made changes to consistently use an EObject.
Releasing classes BeanPArt and CompositeAddDecoderHelper.

Thanks Jon for finding these out.
